Does this mean RPGs are banned on other video game boards? No! /vrpg/ is just a separate board specifically focused on RPGs where discussions about your favorite games can thrive.

Please familiarize yourself with the rules and remember to use the spoiler function where appropriate!

Please note that, like /v/, "Generals"—long-term, one-after-the-other, recurring threads about a specific game are not permitted on /vrpg/. Such threads belong on >>>/vg/.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
It's not the first JRPG that plays with the concept of darkness. I knew it would be there and I thought I could forgive them.

See, in Japanese the connotation of darkness is closer to words like "secret, hidden, and unknown". It's not completely senseless in English because we have phrases like "to be left in the dark". Although that usage is closer to ignorance; you know, someone who's not "bright" is a "dim wit".

The magical substance, darkness, corrupts nature both physical and mental. It makes sense that someone touched by darkness would lose their memory and sense of self. But it makes less sense that things transformed by darkness turn into something savage and aggressive. In theory you could apply the principle of darkness to zealots, racists, autistics, and erase what they think they know along with any reason to impose. This is where you have to do mental gymnastics to consider the principles of light: truth, understanding, and harmony.
So you can reason the forest wants to kill you because the corruption has removed "harmony". For the sake of the game, we overlook the fact that everything is united against you. It's an illusion of harmony. Realistically, the forest should be a battle royal with monsters fighting monsters.

DnD based magic systems are retarded and have zero rhyme and reason in their progression. In Kingmaker and WOTR, your caster character can somehow learn the level 7 firestorm spell even if they don't know the level 3 fireball spell. Once you reach the level requirement, you can choose advanced illusion spells like Weird even if the only spells you have are evocation spells. It doesn't make any sense. It gets even stupider when you characters can learn spells like Greater Dispel Magic despite not learning the much more basic Dispel Magic.

What is the best magic system in fantasy rpgs?

last_replies.com:
>>2869982
>Don't hoard your gold, there's no point
HARD disagree.
If you're playing as Hawke, you need 10k gold for the Ancient Texts
If you want more than 1 spellcaster, especially using fusion spells, those 2400G and 3600G spells add up quickly
There's a lot of free armor available through early game chests, recruiting and booting characters, and some quest rewards which is more than enough to protect you for the majority of the game.
The best purchases, apart from spells for your casters, are the endgame set of armor because nothing really compares defensively except for extremely rare RNG drops.
There are also some weapon types which are best purchased from the shops, and of course blacksmithing is huge and... not expensive per se but you need some gold to do it.

>Just invest in whatever class your characters come by default
That varies wildly depending on the character, and also what you want them to do.
Thief and Herbalist are horrible in combat and are classes you want to switch off of ASAP, but they also have useful field skills that you want at least someone to have levelled up.
Entertainer has decent combat skills, and the only Basic class with Covert, but for characters wanting to capitalize on Martial Arts, Geckling Knight is superior, whereas Swordsman, Castle Knight and Rosalian Officer outperform as Long Sword users. Basically a jack of 2 trades, master of none.
Frontier Guard is similarly outperformed by the same classes.
Kjar Sentinel runs circles around Ranger as a dedicated bow-user.
Swordsman is alright. Although Grey can't use his unique Katana in-class, strangely enough.
Valhallan Warrior is really useful... to get to level 3, because then you have 3/7 skills you need to turn Sif into a Warrior.
Pirate is one of, if not the, best Basic class to actually stay in the entire game. They have in-class healing which is almost guaranteed to go first, and Foils and Hand Axes are both useful and versitile weapon types.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2870041
The strongest Basic classes, are Craftsman, Geckling Knight, Pirate, and maybe Trader if you know the ins and outs of trading.
For Advanced classes there are a slew of good options including Castle Knight, Draconite, Estamirian Rebel, Imperial Scholar, Kjar Sentinel, Martial Artist, Rosalian Mage, Rosalian Officer, and Wizard, which offer so much more for a little more investment.
Then there are the Legendary classes which require significantly more investment. For veterans, most Legendary classes aren't worth sacrificing the extra benefits from Advanced classes, but for new players having something like a Warrior, a Cleric, or a Bard can be a major boon.
Grinding jewels to fix classes is a chore compared to getting it right the first time.
I'd strongly recommend looking at which Advanced classes match each party member's play style the most, getting at least one of them to level 3, then seeing which field skills you're missing and levelling those up to 3 as well. Since there's no Advanced class with Gathering or Strategy (unless Remaster added one I don't know about) you'll probably want to buy those skills individually, unless you plan on making one of your characters something like a Cleric.

>I took the dive and immediately was rewarded with 1000 gold from a node that I previously was not able to get
Levelling field skills is absolutely worth it. Search for finding chests and ore, gathering for mining, strategy for picking locks and disarming traps, survival is required for certain dungeons, covert... is more quality of life, but if you're bad at dodging than stealth is a viable option, and trade is really useful, but more of an advanced strategy than something a beginner can invest in and immediately see returns.
Usually you can get each skill to 3 and call it good, but there are a few fixed locations which require Lv5 Climb, Lv5 Pick Locks, etc., but no need to stress out too hard over grinding field skills that high

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2867737
Good, gameplay-focused RPG Maker games:

Ruina: Fairy Tale of the Forgotten Ruins - Dungeon crawling RPG inspired by tabletop RPGs. Great exploration, thick atmosphere, lots of choices in how to handle events, and outstanding lore writing.

Helen's Mysterious Castle - Great and unique duel-based combat system. Lots of charm. Its character building system is based entirely around equipment and gives the game plenty of replay value.

Standstill Girl - Similar combat to Helen's. I don't think it's quite as good as Helen, but it's still worth playing.

Liar Jeannie in Crucifix Kingdom - By the author of Standstill Girl. Party-based dungeon crawler where you control two human characters and can summon up to two defeated enemies as undead. Good combat and interesting equipment strategy. Has the best status ailment system I've ever seen in an RPG.

Demon King Chronicle - Exploration-focused RPG. Doesn't have a lot of dialogue, but what's there is good. Has solid, attrition-based gameplay, and a unique equipment system that adds a lot of strategy. The English version is no longer officially available, but unofficially you can get it here: https://files.catbox.moe/l02ghi.zip

Black Souls and Black Souls 2 - Free roaming H-RPGs. You can turn the hentai off if you want. Easily competes with the top tier of WRPGs in terms of choices and consequence. Very strong in exploration. Combat is above average but nothing amazing.

Hat World - An RPG combining SaGa-like combat and character building with platforming exploration not unlike the original Valkyrie Profile's. Has a solid battle system and plenty of challenging boss fights. There are six different campaigns to play through, full of likable characters and interesting stories.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2870018
Sequel series esp. Sequel Colony - Conventional, high quality, H JRPGs. Likable characters, generally weak plots. The combat and character building are both above average by JRPG standards.

Asylum - A side game to the Sequel series, this one is lighter on dialogue and heavier on gameplay. Very open exploration. Also an H game though the H scenes are 100% optional.

JoJo's Bizarre Adventure: The 7th Stand User - A retelling of JoJo's Bizarre Adventure: Stardust Crusaders where you play as an OC who joins Jotaro et al. on their quest to defeat Dio. There are a ton of different ways events can play out depending on your character's personality, abilities, and choices. This has a ridiculous amount of postgame and NG+ content, including hidden boss battles against the villains of several other JoJo parts. Some of its weaker points include a shallow combat system and somewhat grindy design.

Fumika Fantasy - Semi-open world H JRPG focused on powerleveling. Unique combat system focused on resource management where many of your abilities don't use up your turn. NPCs are surprisingly reactive and there are a ton of hidden scenes and alternate outcomes to events, though most of that just leads to hidden hentai scenes with only a minority of those events having gameplay relevance. It has extensive NG+ features, but the real challenge comes from trying to beat the final boss on your first try without using NG+.

Touhou Wandering Souls - A collectathon/brawler/platformer. I have no idea why RPG Maker was used for this, but it's very long, good, and challenging. Lunatic difficulty is recommended for those who can handle it.

Takamakuran games - Namely MY]R, A New Game, and The Mercenary's Adventure. An interesting set of H RPGs with hidden depths and a lot of personality. A New Game is easily the best of the lot, though the other two still have their own merits.

threads.sub: What is the correct mindset to enjoy DRPGs?
threads.com:
I've tried playing some DRPGs and there's a lot of things I like about them:
>party management
>free character creation, allowing for a multitude of approaches
>first person exploration is usually immersive
>I like drawing maps and making my own notes

Even though I like all these things, there's one thing that always filters me in these games: the combat. No matter how much I try, it seems that all the DRPGs really on two types of battles: the ones where you mash attack until the enemy is dead without worrying about anything and the ones where you try to mash attack to win but the enemy completely destroys your whole party with just one attack. This second option usually becomes a RNG fest, because while the enemy always has this attack that wipes your party, it can use it on turn 1, turn 10 or never use it, so it all comes down to luck.
So, what you do to enjoy this? Do you just accept that combat is shit and decide to have a good time with the remaining characteristics of the game?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2868173
there is reason people talk shit about 6.
Grinding shouldn't be the goal, that's where 6 failed.
Disgaea never was about grinding. It was about exploiting game mechanics in your advantage in a way you like it, partly sandbox SRPG where you could create character you want and as powerful you want.
I'm not saying grinding didn't exist. But it mostly was a thing in post game or NG+. It never really affected normal gameplay, and normally Disgaea was still competent SRPG.
And "grinding" is different for each. One can just grind things via repeating battles over and over, other can start figuring out various more optimal or fun ways to get powerful faster. Third would just enjoy item world and completely different way of getting stronger. It's about figuring game mechanics and using them in your advantage.

6 abandons that in sake of making "grinding" your goal.
You can argue that autobattle is "just another mechanic to figure out and exploit" using my arguments above, but as you said yourself - it trivializes whole game. You now do not need to figure out game in general, when you can just set up autobattle on repeat, put game running for a night or such, and that's it.
It doesn't make it more fun that, dunno, playing cookie clicker. If you just like numbers go up, there are a lot of incremental games out there.

Grinding as a word has bad reputation, but people generally still grind because base gameplay loop is good enough or just enjoyable, and reward for effort you put into figuring out the mechanics and making it work, getting all set up and making stuff the way you want - is all the sweeter after putting some grinding in.

Now you can get anything with simple repeating autobattle. Why play the game at all then? If "number go up" became entire goal while discrediting anything else, I'll find about same amount of enjoyment in any mobile dopamine game out there. This isn't why I played Disgaea.

So autobattle can go fuck itself.

A wargame is a clash between 2 opposing forces where the objective is to merely win. An RPG is PvM where each player generally has rewards distributed evenly amongst themselves. So in a computer wargame the computer simulates an opponent, whereas in a computer RPG it simulates a DM guiding a campaign.

And many other things. But that is the biggest one.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: Is ちんちん避けゲーム the most innovative RPG of the decade? Undertale did come out a year prior, but ちんちん避けゲーム basically does it all better, deviating completely from the standard RPG formula instead of shyly stepping around it and changing things here and there. The writing is impeccable, unlike childish, derivative "haha it's not like Final Fantasy you guys!" western indie games. It is not merely subversive for the sake of being subversive or to shock the player, it actually has something to tell. ちんちん避けゲーム will make you laugh and cry, sometimes both at once. In my opinion, it is a groundbreaking RPG, albeit one that is unknown outside of Japan. It even introduces a social element with it being hosted on NicoNico. It does drag on a little bit, but overall it is a joy to experience through and through. I truly believe that ちんちん避けゲーム is one of those unique games that you will think about for days after completing it, and never forget.

The only similarity they have is that they both have recruitable enemies as party members. One is a PVP focused game structured like a TCG or board game, the other is a campaign focused game structured around large parties and resource sustain.

>>2860473
Vivec is designed like a series of castles. There's enough light and water to cultivate plants, but the light is sourced internally to remove weak spots in the outer walls, and the water sources are largely made inaccessible to saboteurs. The corridors all look alike to confuse invaders, the interior feels cramped so it's difficult to fight inside without special training, the foreigner's quarter only has the one bridge connecting it to the other cantons as a safety measure while the great houses can reinforce one another through the first floor walkways, the civilian residential cantons are only accessible via the warrior-heavy Redoran and Arena cantons and the Tribunal temple is behind even those.
The cantons themselves are good enough because Vivec city exists because of Vivec the god choosing to live there and it is important more for diplomatic, political, and religious reasons than because it is this natural trade hub. The unnatural planned feel of the place is similar to Canberra.
That said, they could probably be using the outdoor surface area on the higher levels for agriculture and have a slum city of wooden walkways, living boats, and huts on stilts on the waterfront to represent urban sprawl and imply the existence of a fishing industry. The fact it didn't kind of implied Vvardenfell's population has been decreasing for several decades.

Do not listen to this man.
Get the min requirements for your weapon and spells, then pump two thirds of your levels into vigor. Vigor is the single most important stat, damage can be buffed but you will be doing zero damage if you die.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2867800
>I will admit that I am a retard and I decided not to see any guides and just winging it the whole time.
that's the opposite of being a retard

decide what kind of weapon you like to use. from your screenshot you have the axe, it has D scaling in both STR and DEX so level those up. don' tforget to upgrade your weapon. you also seem to be using incantations, so level some faith but not that much is needed.
in ER, Vigor (your health bar) is easily the most important stat. don't forget to level it up. Endurance is of course vital as well.

also you seem to have Heavy Load, drop that down to Medium (or light). Heavy Load makes your roll very slow and basically useless. this is probably the biggest noob pitfall in these games.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2867800
You need more Vigor. The game will begin shitting out damage late game and you'll get 1 shot unless you have 40 MINIMUM. Upgrade the weapon you like using a lot, check out what the scaling is on it, and then keep leveling that stat. Since you started as the Confessor, I would try leveling Vigor > Strength > Endurance >Faith > Mind in that order from most important to least important. If you keep doing that you'll have enough stats to use any strength/faith weapons you find exploring (there's quite a few of them)

Also good on you for not using guides. The beauty of this game is in exploring and discovering your own way to play. Don't become another mindless drone like the millions of other cookie cutter players out there.

>>2869289
For the Trails series specifically, the order would be
> Trails in the Sky 1/2/3
> Trails from Zero
> Trails of Azure (Not localized yet, but there's a fan patch)
> Trails of Cold Steel 1/2/3/4
> Hajimeri no Kiseki (Not localized yet)
> Kiro no Kiseki (Not localized yet)

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2869289
I want to see more translations of the pre trails stuff. The PSP ports were hardly what you'd call good and there's the dragon slayer games too.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2869289
>If I want to enjoy the story without missing much, which series can I start with? Which game?
I'm not super familiar with the pre-sky games but there is the Gagharv trilogy (Legend of Heroes 3-5 in Japan) but I've heard the translation is so fucking bad those are not even worth playing and I don't believe any sort of alternative fan translation exists. Then Dragon Slayer 1/2 are related but so far from Sky onward previous games before Sky have been completely unrelated.

>>2869327
Pretty much this with Azure only being a few months away for it's official localization Japanese release order is basically the only way to go. With how damn good the Zero PC port (if that's your preferred platform) is compared to PSP emulation or getting the old PC ports working just wait for the official release of Azure. I imagine the console ports of Zero as well is significantly better on consoles as compared to the old releases. CS1/2 take place parallel Zero/Azure and you can play CS1 before those games but the timeline converges late into CS2 so I wouldn't recommend any divergence from Japanese release order other than possibly CS1 anytime after Trails the 3rd.

There is also Nayuta no Kiseki that came out between Azure/CS1 and is getting an English release next year but I've heard that is spinoff game in the same world but pretty much entirely unrelated.

tl;dr: play JP release order

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Looting in warpigs:
>finish a battle
>individually search each and every enemy's corpse and click "take all" along with collecting random bits of cutlery and other garbage littering the room
>become overburdened with useless vendor trash that only exists to be sold
>spend the next few minutes figuring out how to most efficiently distribute the weight between your party, changing equipment to maximise strength bonuses as you do
>head to town to sell everything, making sure to give it all to the party member with the highest barter skill first
>go back to get the rest of the loot
>turns out the merchant doesn't have enough money to buy everything

Looting in jarpigs:
>finish battle
>results screen shows any items you automatically looted, which you can usually carry with effectively no limit
>that's it

Why is it still like this? I'm not even trying to go full weeb and say jarpigs are totally superior, there are definitely things warpigs do better but this isn't one of them. Seriously, why do encumbrance mechanics even still exist? They can't be for realism because they're usually generous enough to let you carry way more than you ever could in reality, and they aren't there as a strategic constraint on the amount of resources you can carry because consumables are typically light and make up maybe 20% of the total weight at most. I like inventory limits in survival horror and some other genres but in any RPG where looting is a major component of the gameplay they need to go, unless maybe the game is really trying hard to be at least somewhat realistic.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2856695
Solasta is a straight implementation of the D&D 5e SRD and gets this right. There is a group called the "Scavengers" that goes to all the locations you visit and kill things, including random battles on the road, and picks up all the loot for you. So instead of lugging twenty leather armors back, you just go check in with the Scavengers in town and they show you a list of everything they picked up from your battlefields. You have the option to keep any items that you might want, like if there is a suit of plate mail or magical item you missed while you were there, and otherwise you just hit "Sell All" and get the gold. It's pretty great because you can just ignore all the trash loot out in the field and then get to pick up your pile of gold when you get back to town.

If I were to make a D&D style CRPG, I would 100% copy that system.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: Do people ACTUALLY play imagination time in RPGs?
threads.com:
Like, I definetly understand making a backstory for your character and thinking of his personality, maybe adding more flavor to some flat dialogue options like how Skyrim dialogues are super general so you could imagine you said some extra words.

But i've stumbled upon people that actually imagine entire new scenarios, entire new scenes with companions, entire new fights, entire new missions.
Why? Why would someone ever do that?

If a game is so empty to the point you have to start imagining things happen, why even play it? Take Morrowind for example, the world is empty, the game has nothing to do beyond walking and clicking continue on each wall of text. Yet i've seen people tell me they made entire elaborated stories that they put into play through their minds and that's the reason Morrowind is such a good RPG

Like... what? The dude tellls me "I made up this backstory for my Khajiit that his mother was killed by an orc so he hates orcs and now he kills all orcs on sight" and i'm like... dude you can't roleplay that in game, the game doesn't give you the tools, but no, he insisted "dude i can approach an orc and kill it completly validating my headcanon". But that is BEYOND STUPID.

There are games that actually give you dialogue options to expand your backstory, Skyrim itself has several talks about your parents with Serana. But none of that is in Morrowind, so... why? Why would anyone go through the effort of making headcanons they can't actually play in RPGs that don't give them the tools to exercise said roleplaying?

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Daggerfall requires a lot of effort on the player to enjoy. A lot of suspension of disbelief. But if you allow yourself to be fooled, it is actually a very fun game. Even though every quest and city is procedurally generated, after you've been playing for a while you kind of allow the illusion that every location is unique to grow on you. You get a sense of scale and realism that no other RPG offers.

I remember Zaric saying that every region in Daggerfall felt unique to him. I thought this was nonsense. How could a region feel unique when it uses the exact same generation algorithm as every other generic region in the game? I didn't understand this until I properly played Daggerfall and gave it a chance rather than dismissing it as procedurally generated garbage like I had done before. For example, over time you remember certain town layouts, you find a city with all the right services that your character requires in the one place, or you grow fond of a city that you've done a lot of quests in. And after a while of helping people out you see your reputation in a region has grown, it feels good that your actions in this world actually mean something.

Daggerfall definitely has something that no other RPG I've played has. A sense of immersion that you really are just an itinerant adventurer living in a fantasy world. Even though it's from 1996 it feels surprisingly modern in the amount of freedom it gives you.

Of course, the Unity version and shit ton of mods help a lot too. There are a lot of quest and world overhaul mods so the game doesn't feel so samey all the time.

>>2862961
This is actually a problem of weapon tiers, rpgs tend to have implicit tiers of weaponry in which certain weapons are very similar, but even the best weapon of a previous tier can hardly stack up to a common weapon of the next tier. This is not a problem per se, otherwise finding one of the good weapons on the left would mean you could stop playing the equipment optimisation game for the next 3 hours.

This is however only unsatisfying if a: you get the fancy weapons of the last tier too shortly before the common weapons of the next tier or b: the game has no use for fancy weapons of a lower tier anymore

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
>Braith (in Whiterun) has a little backstory where if you follow her home, you discover that her parents ignore her, hence her attention seeking behavior
>Flame spells boil small bodies of water
>Shadow markings outside buildings created by Thieves Guild to mark opportunities/warnings (but you have to read the book in the cistern to understand what the markings mean)
>Birds have nests they return to periodically and a small NPC schedule
>Heimskr is either made homeless or jailed after the Battle of Whiterun
>Anise (the witch in the shack) is sisters with Moira, the same Hagraven you "marry" in "A Night to Remember"
>Fultheim is a former Blade (if you check his items, the books in his room and ask the innkeeper about him)
>You can use a calming spell on Boethia's Champion to engage in dialog with him rather than killing him, and it turns out he wanted to turn his back on violence/the daedra
>If you steal the soul gem in Arondil's lair without him noticing, his servant-ghost turns on him
>You can give the Jagged Crown to the rival faction to the one you've joined up with, which allows you to defect
>Lost Prospect, an otherwise abandoned, empty mine has a whole little story (not marked) with a journal detailing how the owner gradually loses hope as they only turn up small quantities of quicksilver and feels his partner has run off and abandoned him. His partner, if you check a hidden chamber behind the waterfall, didn't die and was instead crushed by a collapsing tunnel (that leads into a chamber full of gold)

What are your favorite little details from Skyrim, /vrpg/?
